awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nanodiamond Particle Fabrication by Confined Laser Shock Detonation for Drug Delivery and Other Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanodiamonds, or nanosized diamond particles, have been widely explored as drug delivery vehicles and bio-imaging agents for biomedical treatments ranging from oncology to infection to regenerative medicine.  However, the manufacture of medical quality nanodiamonds is difficult, costly, and energy intensive.  The existing methods for nanodiamond fabrication often rely on a chemical detonation process, which suffers from poor controllability, complex experimental set-ups, and safety issues.  This award supports fundamental research to provide knowledge needed for the development of a simple and cost-effective nanomanufacturing process to fabricate nanodiamonds under ambient conditions.  Using this easy and viable route for nanodiamond fabrication, many complex nanodiamond-based devices for biomedical, electronics, and optics applications can be built at low cost.  Such a capability impacts key U.S. industries thus enhancing national prosperity and security.  The research results will be integrated into a comic book -- Nanodiamond Nora and Neal -- targeted at engaging K-12 students.  In addition, this project provides an integrated training platform for undergraduate and graduate students, and promotes broadening participation of women and underrepresented students in research.

This project aims to establish a new nanomanufacturing strategy for nanodiamond fabrication.  It is hypothesized that the laser-induced plasma in the nanosecond pulsed laser shock processing, can provide sufficient energy input and duration to promote the graphite-to-diamond phase transition.  To test this hypothesis, a confined laser shock detonation approach is planned to realize the scalable nanomanufacturing of nanodiamonds at room-temperature and in open air, through utilizing high-energy laser-matter interaction phenomena.  The major research objective is to establish a fundamental understanding of mechanisms involved in the confined laser shock detonation process that are responsible for the growth of nanodiamonds.  First-principles modeling and molecular dynamics simulations performed at ASU and UNR, help understand the laser-graphite interactions and the plasma dynamics that lead to the graphite-to-diamond phase transition.  Biocompatibility of laser-fabricated nanodiamonds is evaluated through collaboration between ASU and UCLA to demonstrate potential applications in drug delivery and bio-imaging.  This project contributes to advances in laser-based nanomanufacturing and innovations in nanomaterials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts

  1. The research team has carried out experimental studies on confined laser shock detonation (CLSD) to manufacture nanodiamonds (NDs). Figure 1a in our paper [1] shows the experimental setup of the CLSD process. Figure 1b in [1] shows TEM characterization of CLSD manufactured NDs. As observed, nanosized diamond particles smaller than 10 nm were formed. To have a closer observation, one diamond crystal was magnified in Figure 1b in [1].
  2. The research team developed a first-principle based model to predict laser-matter interaction and its effect on plasma dynamics during CLSD. As observed in Figure 5 in [1], the developed model can predict the temporal and spatial distribution of the electron temperature, electron density, plasma pressure and particle velocity during the laser induced plasma hydrodynamics. Through analyzing the heat and plasma pressure propagated to graphite layer in deeper depth as shown in Figures 5e and 5f in [1], we can find an optimized window for graphite-to-diamond phase transition.
  3. The research team developed a MD simulation framework to simulate the graphite-to-diamond phase transition as affected by plasma variables in the CLSD process. As shown in Figure 7 in [1], carbon atoms relocated to new positions and re-configured to form new vertical bonds after CLSD processing at plasma temperature of 0.39 eV and plasma pressure of 44 GPa, indicating transition of carbon atoms from sp2 to sp3 bonds.
  4. The research team integrated first-principles modeling with MD simulation to predict ND nucleation and growth during CLSD. The simulation results elucidate the confining effect in determining the material responses to laser irradiation.  As a key result, the laser fluence threshold for ND nucleation is predicted, as shown in Figure 8a in [1].  Moreover, the carbon phase transition rate as affected by CLSD processing parameters can be quantitatively evaluated, as depicted in Figure 8b in [1]. 
  5. The research team developed an MD-based simulation framework, capable of simulating the graphite-to-diamond phase transition as affected by shockwave propagation and reflection in the CLSD process. Figure 2 in our paper [2] depicts the shockwave propagation and compression induced atoms reconfiguration and layers restructuring in the graphite model during the CLSD process. A clear visualization of the graphite structure evolution during the 2 km/s shockwave propagation process can be observed in Figure 4b in [2]. It is found that the graphite-to-diamond phase transformation is related to the reflection of the shockwave.
  6. To verify the biocompatibility of laser-fabricated NDs, the PIs have developed a process using 3D printing to fabricate ND-filled PLA composites for the biocompatibility tests. The samples are seeded with hMS cells (PT-2501)  in a 12 well plate, then add the CellTiter 96® AQueous One Solution reagent to the growth media in the well, incubate (37℃, 5% CO2) the plate to allow the reagent to enter the cells and be metabolized by the cells, and eventually record the absorbance of the liquid in the 96-well plate at 490nm using a 96-well plate reader on day 1 and day 7. The fluorescent microscope images show that the cells grew well on the ND-PLA samples and nuclei are clearly observed when compared to PLA samples. There is a significant increase in the number of cells on day 7 which indicates the cell growth.

Outcomes of this award:

The project resulted in five conference presentations, one conference poster, two conferences papers published, two journal papers published. In specific, journal papers [1] and [2] have been published. Two conference papers have been published in Proceedings of the ASME 2019 14th International Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference. Three conference presentations have been presented in the 2021 and 2022 AFOSR/NSF Technical Exchange on Biophysics and Nanomanufacturing. Two conference presentations have been presented at the ASME 2019 14th International Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference. One conference poster, entitled “Confined Laser Shock Detonation to Form Nanodiamonds with Nitrogen-Vacancy Center”, has been presented in the 149th Annual Meeting & Exhibition TMS 2020.

In addition, this project has provided training for three graduate students at ASU and two graduate students at ISU/UNR, giving them the opportunity to engage in advanced manufacturing process design and simulation. Additionally, the students also gained experience with written and oral communication. The PI has integrated the theme of this project into curricula at UNR and ISU, including ME354 and ME454/654 at UNR, and IE 248  and IE 645 at ISU.

References:

[1]. X. Zhang, H. Sun, B. Mao, R. Dai, H. Zhuang, Y. Liao*, Q. Nian, "Nanosecond Laser Shock Detonation of Nanodiamonds: from Laser-Matter Interaction to Graphite-to-Diamond Phase Transition", International Journal of Extreme Manufacturing, 4, 015401 (2022)

[2]. H. Sun, X. Jiang, R. Dai, X Zhang, H. Zhuang, Y. Liao*, Q. Nian, "Understanding the Mechanism of Shockwave Induced Graphite-to-Diamond Phase Transition", Materialia, 24, 101487 (2022).

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2022
Modified by: Yanyao Jiang
por.por_txt_cntn:
Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts

 The research team has carried out experimental studies on confined laser shock detonation (CLSD) to manufacture nanodiamonds (NDs). Figure 1a in our paper [1] shows the experimental setup of the CLSD process. Figure 1b in [1] shows TEM characterization of CLSD manufactured NDs. As observed, nanosized diamond particles smaller than 10 nm were formed. To have a closer observation, one diamond crystal was magnified in Figure 1b in [1].
The research team developed a first-principle based model to predict laser-matter interaction and its effect on plasma dynamics during CLSD. As observed in Figure 5 in [1], the developed model can predict the temporal and spatial distribution of the electron temperature, electron density, plasma pressure and particle velocity during the laser induced plasma hydrodynamics. Through analyzing the heat and plasma pressure propagated to graphite layer in deeper depth as shown in Figures 5e and 5f in [1], we can find an optimized window for graphite-to-diamond phase transition.
The research team developed a MD simulation framework to simulate the graphite-to-diamond phase transition as affected by plasma variables in the CLSD process. As shown in Figure 7 in [1], carbon atoms relocated to new positions and re-configured to form new vertical bonds after CLSD processing at plasma temperature of 0.39 eV and plasma pressure of 44 GPa, indicating transition of carbon atoms from sp2 to sp3 bonds.
The research team integrated first-principles modeling with MD simulation to predict ND nucleation and growth during CLSD. The simulation results elucidate the confining effect in determining the material responses to laser irradiation.  As a key result, the laser fluence threshold for ND nucleation is predicted, as shown in Figure 8a in [1].  Moreover, the carbon phase transition rate as affected by CLSD processing parameters can be quantitatively evaluated, as depicted in Figure 8b in [1]. 
The research team developed an MD-based simulation framework, capable of simulating the graphite-to-diamond phase transition as affected by shockwave propagation and reflection in the CLSD process. Figure 2 in our paper [2] depicts the shockwave propagation and compression induced atoms reconfiguration and layers restructuring in the graphite model during the CLSD process. A clear visualization of the graphite structure evolution during the 2 km/s shockwave propagation process can be observed in Figure 4b in [2]. It is found that the graphite-to-diamond phase transformation is related to the reflection of the shockwave.
To verify the biocompatibility of laser-fabricated NDs, the PIs have developed a process using 3D printing to fabricate ND-filled PLA composites for the biocompatibility tests. The samples are seeded with hMS cells (PT-2501)  in a 12 well plate, then add the CellTiter 96® AQueous One Solution reagent to the growth media in the well, incubate (37℃, 5% CO2) the plate to allow the reagent to enter the cells and be metabolized by the cells, and eventually record the absorbance of the liquid in the 96-well plate at 490nm using a 96-well plate reader on day 1 and day 7. The fluorescent microscope images show that the cells grew well on the ND-PLA samples and nuclei are clearly observed when compared to PLA samples. There is a significant increase in the number of cells on day 7 which indicates the cell growth.

The project resulted in five conference presentations, one conference poster, two conferences papers published, two journal papers published. In specific, journal papers [1] and [2] have been published. Two conference papers have been published in Proceedings of the ASME 2019 14th International Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference. Three conference presentations have been presented in the 2021 and 2022 AFOSR/NSF Technical Exchange on Biophysics and Nanomanufacturing. Two conference presentations have been presented at the ASME 2019 14th International Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference. One conference poster, entitled "Confined Laser Shock Detonation to Form Nanodiamonds with Nitrogen-Vacancy Center", has been presented in the 149th Annual Meeting & Exhibition TMS 2020.

In addition, this project has provided training for three graduate students at ASU and two graduate students at ISU/UNR, giving them the opportunity to engage in advanced manufacturing process design and simulation. Additionally, the students also gained experience with written and oral communication. The PI has integrated the theme of this project into curricula at UNR and ISU, including ME354 and ME454/654 at UNR, and IE 248  and IE 645 at ISU.
